title: Boris Johnson, right now we ‘crusties’ are the most united thing in Westminster
text:
I refuse to be complacent in a system that is destroying my future (Picture: Guy Smallman / Getty Images)

It’s rare that you get to feel powerful as a teenager. Most days are spent struggling to keep your own life under control.

Just the idea of having an influence in decision-making, beyond A-level choices, is something we rarely get to experience.

But, occasionally – like when you and fellow teenagers go on strike and protest climate change and in turn irritate the prime minister into calling people like you a ‘uncooperative crustie’ – you realise the power in your own words and actions.

When Boris Johnson referred to the thousands of climate activists blockading London as ‘uncooperative crusties’ this week he gave fuel to a fire burning in all of us.

That statement was not the words of someone who feels indifferent — that was the immature aggression of someone who feels threatened, someone who realises they are losing a battle. Because politicians do not issue angry statements unless they are afraid.

The climate justice movement is just made up of people, who might have absolutely nothing in common except one shared goal: a livable planet and a better future.

The unity you see on the streets is far greater than what you see in Parliament. The uncooperative behaviour that so many politicians have been quick to condemn is global cooperation on an enormous scale.

The uncertainty we face cannot, and will not, be solved by – for lack of a better word – childish bullying

It is thousands of people working together to fight for the survival of our planet and all the life that depends on it. The community that has been built on the streets of London could not exist without cooperation — generalisations and stereotypes from our politicians do not change the fact that the climate justice movement is diverse, it is powerful and it is united.

For every ‘traditional’ environmentalist on the streets right now there is a doctor, a lawyer, a teacher, a parent with their child standing alongside them.

The uncertainty we face cannot and will not be solved by childish bullying (Picture: REUTERS/Henry Nicholls)

Solidarity is lacking in the political dialogue that dominates our conversations, our media and our lives. People are angry and afraid, and rightfully so. We live in a time of uncertainty. But the uncertainty we face cannot and will not be solved by — for lack of a better word —childish bullying.

I don’t take particular offence to what he said. He has used language far worse to many other groups and individuals.

Advertisement

However, there is actually some truth in his words: I refuse to be complacent in a system that is destroying my future. I refuse to stop fighting.

So condemn us all you want. Just remember, insults and stereotypes are nothing more than a waste of time — time we cannot afford to lose.

Time we don’t have. Time that is costing people their lives.

This is a reminder to our government: We would not be here if you had done your jobs. If you hadn’t continued in your oblivious support for fracking and airport expansion. If you were on track to meet emissions goals, if your priorities were in the right place, then the streets of London would not be the home of a rebellion.

It is your inaction that has led us here and we are facing a crisis. We are facing an emergency of enormous scale and we need to see more than words, supportive or otherwise, from our government.

We need to see action.
